info.name: Realbeast API
info.description:
# Introduction
The Realbeast API allows for interaction with our systems backend - allowing inventory to be edited, new products to be added, and more. 

# Overview
Things that the developers should know about

# Authentication
You will want to use basic authentication with the following login - it should be setup in Postman if you are viewing it from there. 

- Username: `admin`
- Password: `12345`

The admin cannot be deleted. 

# Error Codes
Bad requests are the most often - for example, when you try to access an item that does not exist, it will give you an HTTP 400 / Bad Request.

item.name: Product API
Get a list of all products

request.description:
This is the fastest way to get a preview of all of the products carried across the system, returning a list of all products.

The ID is included in all get requests, so that subsequent API endpoints can be used.

response.name: Get a list of all products

request.description:
Updates a product. Supports partial updates.

Updating a product will clear the brand, product type and color fields.
Allows for new products to be added. All of the product fields must be filled in for this to succeed.

response.name: Add a new product

request.description: Deletes a product from the system. All other values relying on a product are also deleted by cascading the database.
Retrieves information about a specific product. Includes ID for convenience.

response.name: Get a product

item.description:
The Product API allows products to be created, modified, added and deleted. 

There are a couple examples included for you to try out!

Almost all of these rely on accessing a product through it's ID. The ID can be found by first querying the list of all products (see examples). The product with the corresponding ID must exist for you to use it.

Note that the image for each product must already exist in the server folder - the example included already has an image, so no need to worry.

Each product has all of the following attributes:

- `id`: the primary key of a product
- `price`:  the price of a product
- `sex`: the sex the product is defined for- should be "M" for male, "F" for female and "U" for unisex
- `name`: the name of a product
- `description`: the description of a product
- `caption`: the caption of a product, displayed with it's image on the product page
- `img-name`: the name of the image of the product
- `brands`: a list of brands associated with the product 
    - each brand only contain a "brand" field, which can have any value. 
- `product_types`: a list of the product types (shorts, shoes, pants, etc.)
    - each product_type only contain a "product_type" field, which can have any value. 
- `colors`: a list of the colors of a product
    - each color only contain a "color" field, which can have any value.

item.name: User API

request.description:
This is the first look at the User API, and provides a glance at how users are represented by the API. 

-`username`: the primary key of a user (cannot be updated by PUT) 
-  `first_name`: the first name of a user
-  `last_name`: the first name of a user
-  `email`: the first name of a user
-  `profile`: the first name of a user (one-to-one relationship with user)
    - `total_rewards`: the rewards points a user has 
    - `user_type`: the type of user ("Customer", "Staff", or "Owner")
    - `address`: the address of user
    - `phone_number`: the phone number of user
    - `card_no`: the card_no of user
  
The POST request requires some additional attributes to be filled in. See it's documentation for more details

header.value: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS

request.description:
This will update the logged in User. Since this Postman documentation has the logged in admin user, any changes will be reflected in the above request: 'Get a user'.

This allows you to partially update the features of a user.

This request is used to create a new user, and can be performed by any authenticated user. 

The fields for this are a bit different - all must be filled in, with the additional :

- `is_staff`: a boolean attribute, determines whether the user is a staff member or not
- `password`: the password the user will use to log in

header.value: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS

request.description: This will delete the user sending the request! Note that deleting the admin is forbidden, and you may receive this as the output of the request, unless you change the user logged in through Postman.

header.value: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS

item.description:
The User API has a safe-access approach: the logged in user (all API accesses require authentication) can only modify, retrieve and delete their own user.

Users can be created at any time, however with the user POST endpoint (see examples).

item.name: Order API
Get the logged in user's orders

request.description: Returns a list of the orders belonging to the logged in user.

response.name: Get the logged in user's orders

item.name: Get a list of all orders (all users)

request.description: Retrieves a list of all orders, system-wide.

response.name: Get a list of all orders (all users)

request.description: Used to access a particular order using it's ID (ID is specified in all gets).
Used to cancel an order, marking it as cancelled. If this is a users cart, then a new cart is made for the user.

Finalizes an order - used to transform a cart into an order ready to be delivered. 

Only valid if enough of the desired quantity is in stock (if not a restock order) - if invalid, a bad request is returned.

If the order is a cart, then a new cart is made for the user placing the order.

Currently uses a fixed delivery date.

Deletes an order from the system. 

If the order is a cart, it will simply clear all of the items from the cart.

item.name: Add an item to an order

request.description: Adds an item to an order. Requires product_id, size and quantity.

response.name: Add an item to an order

item.name: Get a specific item in a specific order

request.description: Retrieves a specific product entry in an order using the id of the contains entry (shown in GET/POST of Order).

item.name: Modify a specific item in a specific order

request.description: Allows size / quantity to be edited for a specific contains entry (accessed by contains ID, shown in POST/GET request of order).

response.name: Modify a specific item in a specific order

item.description:
Provides access to orders in the system. 

Each order has the following attributes:

- `id`: the id of the order (primary key)
- `username`: the username of the user who this order belongs to 
- `location`: the store the order is from / for
- `delivery_status`: the delivery status of the order
- `contains`: a list of simplified product entries
    - each entry contains: 
    - product_id of the product being ordered: 
    - the quantity of the product being ordered:
    - each entry contains: the size of the product being ordered.  
- `rewards_earned`: the rewards earned by this order
- `total_price`: the total price of the order
- `order_date`: the date the order was placed (not meaningful for carts)
- `delivery_date`: the date the order is expected to be delivered (not meaningful for carts)
- `is_restock`: specifies if this is a product restock order (placed by staff/owners for stores)

item.name: Store API

request.description: Allows for new stores to be created. The owner must exist as a user in the system.
Allows for the owner of a store to be updated, by location name.
Gets information of a specific store, using the specified location name.

item.description:
The Store API provides access to the different stores associated with the Realbeast Shop. 

Each store has the following related information: 
- `location`: the location of each store
- `owner`: the username of the store's owner

Support basic CRUD operations.

item.name: Inventory API

request.description: Gets the inventory of each product across all stores and sizes.

item.name: Get inventory at a specifc store

request.description: Gets a list of all of the inventory objects at a particular location.

response.name: Get inventory at a specifc store

item.name: Get specific product inventory for a specified store

request.description: Even more specific than the last, this returns a list of inventory entries for a specific product at a particular store to be accessed.

response.name: Get specific product inventory for a specified store

item.name: Add a size for a given product at a given store

request.description:
Used to add inventory of a specific product to the system. 
All fields detailed in the inventory API are required.
The most specific GET request of this portion of our API, allows a particular size of a particular product at a particular store to be retrieved.

item.name: Update a product's sizing at a particular location and size

request.description:
Allows a particular size of a particular product at a particular store to be retrieved. See the example. 

The store and location must exist (used to access it). 

Supports partial updates.

item.name: Remove a product size from a store's inventory

request.description: Removes an inventory entry, using the size, location and product.

response.name: Remove a product size from a store's inventory

item.description:
The inventory API is one of the fundamental aspects of our API. This allows different stores inventory levels to be managed and updated. The location, product_id and size make up the primary key. 

Each inventory object contains:

- `location`: the store associated with this inventory entry
- `product_id`: the related product id
- `size`: the size of the inventory entry
- `quantity`: the quantity of the inventory entry
